Article Bimetallic Ni x Fe2– x P cocatalyst with tunable electronic structure for enhanced photocatalytic benzyl alcohol oxidation coupled with H2 evolution over red phosphorus Shuang Li Haili Lin Xuemei Jia * Xin Jin Qianlong Wang Xinyue Li Shifu Chen Jing Cao * Key Laboratory of Green and Precise Synthetic and Applications, Ministry of Education; Anhui Provincial Key Laboratory of Synthetic Chemistry and Applications; College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Huaibei Normal University, Huaibei 235000, Anhui, China Key Laboratory of Green and Precise Synthetic and Applications Ministry of Education Anhui Provincial Key Laboratory of Synthetic Chemistry and Applications College of Chemistry and Materials Science Huaibei Normal University Huaibei Anhui 235000 China Key Laboratory of Green and Precise Synthetic and Applications, Ministry of Education; Anhui Provincial Key Laboratory of Synthetic Chemistry and Applications; College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Huaibei Normal University, Huaibei 235000, Anhui, China * Corresponding author. Although bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts have attracted considerable interest in photocatalysis research owing to their advantageous thermodynamic characteristics, superstable and efficient cocatalysts have rarely been produced through the modulation of their structure and composition. In this study, a series of bimetallic nickel-iron phosphide (Ni x Fe2–x P, where 0 < x < 2) cocatalysts with controllable structures and overpotentials were designed by adjusting the atomic ratio of Ni/Fe onto nonmetallic elemental red phosphorus (RP) for the photocatalytic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) coupled with hydrogen production. The catalysts exhibited an outstanding photocatalytic activity for benzaldehyde and a high H2 yield. The RP regulated by bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts (Ni x Fe2–x P) demonstrated higher photocatalytic oxidation-reduction activity than that regulated by monometallic phosphide cocatalysts (Ni2P and Fe2P). In particular, the RP regulated by Ni1.25Fe0.75P exhibited the best photocatalytic performance. In addition, experimental and theoretical calculations further illustrated that Ni1.25Fe0.75P, with the optimized electronic structure, possessed good electrical conductivity and provided strong adsorption and abundant active sites, thereby accelerating electron migration and lowering the reaction energy barrier of RP. This finding offers valuable insights into the rational design of highly effective cocatalysts aimed at optimizing the photocatalytic activity of composite photocatalysts. Graphical Abstract A series of bimetallic nickel-iron phosphides (NixFe2-xP) cocatalysts with controllable structure and overpotential were elaborately designed on RP to achieve highly efficient photocatalytic performance for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol coupled with hydrogen production. Keywords Bimetallic phosphides cocatalyst Composition regulation Red phosphorus Selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol H2 1 Introduction The use of solar energy to upgrade biomass derivatives, which are abundant on earth, into high-value-added fuels and chemical feedstocks is a promising approach for improving renewable energy supplies and alleviating environmental problems [ 1–3 ]. The photocatalytic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) coupled with hydrogen (H2) production, which has attracted considerable attention, can realize the full utilization of photogenerated electrons and holes and produce high-value-added chemicals such as benzaldehyde (BAD) and clean energy H2 [ 4–7 ]. However, the low quantum efficiency and delayed kinetic reactions in these photocatalytic systems limit their practical applications. Therefore, the design of an efficient photocatalytic system remains a primary task. Considering that semiconductor photocatalysts with earth-abundant elements are beneficial for large-scale industrial applications, the novel elemental red phosphorus (RP) has been considered a promising candidate material owing to its metal-free nature, low cost, suitable band gap energy, and wide light absorption range [ 8–10 ]. RP has been widely used in various photocatalytic tests for water splitting [ 11–13 ], pollutant degradation [ 14–16 ], bacterial elimination [ 17–19 ], and CO2 reduction [ 20 ]. In particular, a suitable direct bandgap renders RP a promising photocatalyst for BA oxidation coupled with H2 evolution in the solar light spectrum. It should be noted that RP can also be oxidized to PO4 3– and HPO4 2– in water by photoinduced holes under light irradiation. This suggests that RP is stable in non-aqueous systems. Thus, the photocatalytic splitting of BA in a non-aqueous system as a faultless tactic was applied to RP, which not only inhibits the photocorrosion of RP but also makes full use of the photoexcited electrons and holes to produce high-value-added chemicals while achieving H2 evolution. Nevertheless, the rapid recombination rate of carriers results in the low photocatalytic redox activity of pure RP, which highly restricts its practical applications [ 20,21 ]. To overcome these inherent shortcomings, multifarious strategies such as controlling the morphology [ 22 ], depositing cocatalysts [ 23 ], and constructing heterojunctions [ 24 ] have been used to accelerate carrier separation and migration to enhance the photocatalytic activity of RP. Among these, the deposition of a cocatalyst on the surface of the RP not only provides abundant active sites and reduces the reaction energy barrier but also accelerates the separation and migration of carriers [ 25–28 ], which has been regarded as an effective strategy to overcome the above shortcomings. Typical noble metal cocatalysts, including Ru [ 29 ], Au [ 30,31 ], Pd [ 32,33 ], Pt [ 34,35 ], and Ag [ 36 ], have been widely used in the field of photocatalysis, but the low reserves and high costs of such noble metal cocatalysts limit their practical applications. Hence, efficient cocatalysts containing earth-abundant elements have attracted considerable attention by researchers working in the field of photocatalysis. Various cocatalysts with earth-abundant and low-cost elements have been developed, such as metal sulfides [ 37 ], metal phosphides [ 38–40 ], metal carbides [ 41 ], metal oxides [ 42 ], metal borides [ 43 ], metal borides, and metal hydroxides [ 44 ]. In particular, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are among the most promising cocatalyst candidates for modifying semiconductor photocatalysts because of their remarkable electrical conductivity, high stability, and low cost, and they have been frequently considered as substitutes for precious metal cocatalysts. For instance, Li et al. [ 45 ] prepared a series of M 2P/CdIn2S4 (M 2P, M = Fe, Co, and Ni) photocatalysts that displayed excellent activity for H2 production, which was mainly attributed to the synergistic quadripartite modification of M2P at the active site, carrier separation, visible light absorption, and H2 evolution kinetics. Liu et al. [ 46 ] reported that hot electrons produced by CoP nanorods acted as photothermal antennas, enabling their migration to CdZnS to engage in the proton reduction process. Yang et al. [ 47 ] verified that a Ni2P cocatalyst can offer abundant active sites for In2O3 to achieve efficient photocatalytic performance. However, the enhancement effect of monometallic phosphide cocatalysts is still low owing to an inadequate number of reactive sites for potential applications. Recently, bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts [ 48 ] with optimized work functions have led to the formation of unique microstructures and remarkable synergetic effects and have demonstrated outstanding potential in achieving a high-efficiency cocatalyst effect that monometallic phosphide cocatalysts could hardly realize. As demonstrated by some recent studies [ 48,49 ], bimetallic phosphides have superior stability and cocatalytic effects compared to monometallic phosphides, owing to their abundant active sites and unique synergistic effects. Fan et al. [ 48 ] illustrated that NiCoP/g-C3N4 exhibited higher photocatalytic H2 evolution than the corresponding monometallic phosphide/g-C3N4 systems. Similarly, Zhang et al. [ 49 ] showed that NiFeP cocatalysts improved the H2 production of g-C3N4 than monometallic Ni2P and Fe2P. Although bimetallic phosphides have been established as effective cocatalysts for photocatalysis, most studies have primarily concentrated on adjusting their loading amounts within a fixed composition, often overlooking the modulation of the metal-to-metal ratio in these bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts. Specifically, the pathways for photogenerated electron transfer and the reduction of the reaction energy barriers caused by bimetallic phosphides remain unclear. Herein, a series of bimetallic nickel-iron phosphide (Ni x Fe2–x P, 0 < x < 2) cocatalysts were synthesized and assembled with RP to construct a novel Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composite for photocatalytic selective BA oxidation coupled with H2 production. The Ni x Fe2−x P cocatalysts exhibit a tunable structure and overpotential by varying the amounts of Ni and Fe. Notably, Ni1.25Fe0.75P demonstrated an optimized composition and electronic configuration, offering excellent electrical conductivity and numerous active sites, thereby enhancing electron migration and reducing the reaction energy barrier for RP. The RP regulated by bimetallic phosphide Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalysts demonstrates better photocatalytic oxidation–reduction activity than that regulated by monometallic phosphide Ni2P and Fe2P cocatalysts. In particular, RP regulated by Ni1.25Fe0.75P showed the best photocatalytic performance, which was attributed to the Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalyst accelerating electron migration and lowering the reaction energy barrier of RP. This study sought to provide theoretical insights into the design and development of multi-metallic center photocatalytic systems for the visible-light-driven production of high-value-added chemicals and clean hydrogen energy from biomass-derived chemicals. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents All the Chemical reagents, involving ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, 99.0%), sodium hypophosphite monohydrate (NaH2PO2·H2O, 98.0%), and ethanol (CH3CH2OH, 99.7%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (China). Nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O, 99.9%) and commercial red phosphorus (RP, 98.5%) were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4, 99.8%) was purchased from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. Benzyl alcohol (C6H5CH2OH, 99.0%) and N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.8%) were obtained from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd. The 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai) Trading Co., Ltd., and triethanolamine (TEOA) was purchased from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Partnership Enterprise. Carbon tetrachloride (CCl4), butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT), and isopropyl alcohol (IPA) was obtained from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All chemicals were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Deionized water was used throughout the experiments. 2.2 Treatment of RP The RP was prepared using a double hydrothermal method. Commercial, 4.35 g of commercial RP was ground for 30 min and dispersed in 70.0 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, the mixed solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and treated at 200 °C for 10 h. Finally, the products were collected by centrifugation, rinsed with ethanol and deionized water three times each, and then dried in an oven at 80 °C for about 10 h to obtain the product, which were denoted as RP(A). Similar to the above procedure, the as-obtained RP(A) was further treated using the hydrothermal method, and the final product, RP, was gathered as described above. 2.3 Fabrication of NixFe2–xP First, a Ni y Fe1–y C2O4 precursor was prepared using a solvothermal method. Typically, 8.00 mmol of Na2C2O4 (1.07 g), 5.00 mmol of NiCl2·6H2O (1.19 g) and 3.00 mmol of FeCl3·6H2O (0.811 g) was dispersed in 60.0 mL ethylene glycol under stirring. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 170 °C for 24 h. The precipitates were analogously gathered as described above and denoted as Ni0.625Fe0.375C2O4. Similarly, a series of Ni y Fe1–y C2O4 (y = 1.00, 0.875, 0.750, 0.500, 0.375, and 0, where y represents the Ni/(Fe + Ni) molar ratio) was synthesized using the same synthesis process described above. When y = 1.00 and y = 0, the prepared samples were monometallic NiC2O4 and FeC2O4. Subsequently, a series of Ni x Fe2–x P (x = 2y = 2.00, 1.75, 1.50, 1.25, 1.00, 0.750 and 0) was fabricated by phosphating the as-obtained Ni y Fe1–y C2O4 precursor (0.200 g) using NaH2PO2·H2O (1.00 g) in a muffle furnace at 275 °C (5 °C/min) for 2 h. Before the calcination, the Ni y Fe1–y C2O4 precursor and NaH2PO2·H2O were grinded uniformly in a mortar. In addition, the actual Ni and Fe contents of the Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalysts were quantitatively determined using ICP-OES (Table S1). The result indicated that about 79.21 wt% Ni and 1.91 wt% Fe, 77.71 wt% Ni and 2.58 wt% Fe, 77.54 wt% Ni and 2.08 wt% Fe, 37.59 wt% Ni and 2.11 wt% Fe, and 47.09 wt% Ni and 17.5 wt% Fe, were detected in the Ni1.75Fe0.25P, Ni1.5Fe0.5P, Ni1.25Fe0.75P, Ni1Fe1P, and Ni0.75Fe1.25P, respectively. 2.4 Construction of NixFe2–xP/RP composites A variety of Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites were synthesized by the electrostatic self–assembled method. In brief, 0.770 mg of Ni x Fe2–x P was mixed with 100 mg of sample RP in a beaker containing 30.0 mL deionized water and then sonicated for 3 h. After that, the obtained sample was homoplastically collected as above the collection of RP(A), which was marked as 0.77 wt% Ni x Fe2–x P/RP (donated as 0.77Ni x Fe2–x P/RP). Similarly, a series of z wt% Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites (z = 0.190, 0.390, 1.55, and 2.32) were fabricated by altering the weight of Ni x Fe2–x P, which were labeled as 0.19Ni x Fe2–x P/RP, 0.39Ni x Fe2–x P/RP, 1.55Ni x Fe2–x P/RP and 2.32Ni x Fe2–x P/RP, respectively. 2.5 Characterizations First, the surface electrical properties of the as-prepared samples were determined using a Nano ZS90 Zeta sizer. Second, the phase structures of the catalysts were analyzed using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (XRD). Subsequently, the microstructure and surface elemental composition of the samples were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS Sigma 300) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The microstructure was characterized using a JEOL F200 Field transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). Subsequently, the electron migration direction, chemical valence states, and compositions of the materials were analyzed using Shimadzu Axis Supra+ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in situ light irradiation XPS. The light absorption properties were examined with a Shimadzu UV-3600 iplus UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-vis DRS). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the samples were calculated using an ASAP 2460 specific surface area meter. The reaction intermediates were detected using an INVENIO S in situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer. Reactive free radicals were detected using a Bruker A300 electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer (EPR). The recombination rate and average lifetime of the carriers were measured using an Edinburgh Instruments FLS1000 steady-state photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved PL (TRPL) spectrophotometer. The decay curves were fitted using a biexponential decay function: y = y 0 + A 1 e –x/τ1 + A 2 e –x/τ1, and the average PL lifetimes (τ ave) were calculated according to the formula: τ ave = (A 1 τ 1 2 + A 2 τ 2 2)/(A 1 τ 1 + A 2 τ 2). Metallic element content detection for Ni and Fe were performed on a Thermo Fisher iCAPTM 7000 inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). 2.6 Photocatalytic selective BA oxidation coupled with H2 production The photocatalytic selective BA oxidation coupled with H2 production was carried out in MC-SPB10-AG reaction system utilizing an MC-PF300C 300 W Xe lamp furnished with a cut-off filter (λ > 420 nm) as illuminant (Beijing MerryChange Technology Co., Ltd) at 6 °C by circulating water with condensation. In brief, 30 mg of the as-prepared photocatalyst was dispersed in 29.0 mL of DMF containing 1.00 mL of BA solution to form a suspension through ultrasonication. Subsequently, the reaction system and quartz reactor were sealed under vacuum. After irradiation, H2 was detected using the thermal conductive detector (TCD) of a gas chromatograph (Fuli GC9790II) at a given time interval. In addition, the BA conversion efficiency, BAD yield, and selectivity were estimated using Eqs. (1)–(3) [ 50 ]. (1) Conversion of BA = (1 – C t/C 0) × 100% (2) Yield of BAD = C p/C 0 × 100% (3) Selectivity of BAD = C p/(C 0 – Ct ) × 100% where, C 0 and Ct are the initial and final BA concentrations, respectively, C p is the BAD concentration. 2.7 Photoelectrochemical measurement Electrochemical characterizations, such as transient photocurrent (TPC) responses, electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS), and Mott-Schottky (M-S) curves, were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation using 0.100 mol/L Na2HPO4-NaH2PO4 electrolyte solution at room temperature. A three-electrode system consisting of a Pt wire (counter electrode), Ag/AgCl (reference electrode), and a sample film deposited on fluoride-tin oxide (FTO) conductive glass (working electrode) was used. The working electrode was fabricated as follows: 3.00 mg of the sample and 2.00 mL of a mixture containing ethanol, distilled water, and Nafion were mixed evenly. Subsequently, 0.200 mL of the suspension was coated onto a 1 × 1 cm FTO conductive glass and dried in air. 2.8 Theoretical calculations using density functional theory (DFT) All calculations were performed using the projector-augmented plane-wave method, as implemented in the Vienna abinitio simulation package [ 51,52 ]. The generalized gradient approximation (GAA) was selected as the exchange-correlation potential [ 53,54 ]. The configuration was optimized with a maximum pressure on each atom of less than 0.03 eV/Å using an energy criterion of 10–5 eV. A 20 Å vacuumed layer was added perpendicular to the plate, which was used to avoid artificial interactions between periodic images. A 2 × 2 × 1 k mesh was utilized for the Brillouin zone integration. The climbing image nudged elastic band (cNEB) method was used to search for the reaction path and transition state, and vibrational frequency calculations were utilized for further confirmation. To calculate the reaction pathways, the VASPsol plugin [ 55 ], which incorporates an implicit solvent model, was utilized. The dielectric constant was set to 80 for the aqueous solution configuration. In addition, the detailed calculation of apparent quantum yield (AQY) (Text S1) as well as the calculation of surface charges transfer efficiency (η CTE) (Text S2) were given in Electronic Supporting Information (ESI). 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1(a) shows the preparation procedure for the Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites. Firstly, the hydrothermally synthesized RP owned negatively charged with the Zeta potential of –12.8 mV, on the contrary, the Zeta potential of the as-fabricated Ni1.25Fe0.75P had positively charged about 13.9 mV (Fig. S1). The electrostatic interaction between RP and Ni x Fe2–x P allowed the construction of a Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composite via electrostatic self-assembly. SEM was used to observe the microscopic structures of the photocatalysts. It is worth noting that the morphology of bulk Ni x Fe2–x P gradually increased with an increase in the molar ratio of Ni/Fe in Ni x Fe2–x P (Fig. 1(b) and Figs. S2(b)–(e)), which inherits the features of unary Ni2P (Fig. S2(a)). Nevertheless, the morphology of Ni x Fe2–x P was completely different from that of the stick-like structure of Fe2P (Fig. S2(f)). Similar to Ni1.25Fe0.75P (Fig. 1(b)), RP (Fig. 1(c)) and 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP (Fig. 1(d)) exhibited blocky structures. A similar phenomenon was observed for 0.77Ni2P/RP (Fig. S3(a)) and 0.77Fe2P/RP (Fig. S3(b)), both of which are composed of many blocks. TEM analysis was performed to further confirm that Ni1.25Fe0.75P and RP formed a tight interface. As shown in Fig. 1(e), a tight interface was formed between Ni1.25Fe0.75P and RP, and the identity of RP and Ni1.25Fe0.75P was confirmed by TEM analysis based on subsequent EDS elemental mapping of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP (Fig. 1(g)). From the EDS elemental mapping of P and O, it can be seen that P and O were evenly distributed throughout the entire bulk material, mainly because of the presence of P and surface-adsorbed O in RP and Ni1.25Fe0.75P. However, from the EDS elemental mapping of Ni and Fe, it can be seen that Ni and Fe were only distributed in the right bulk material, and there was no distribution of Ni and Fe in the left bulk material. These results further confirm that RP was only distributed on the left bulk material, whereas Ni1.25Fe0.75P was mainly distributed on the right bulk material, thereby further confirming the formation of a tight interface between Ni1.25Fe0.75P and RP (Fig. 1(e)). Subsequently, HRTEM was performed to further study the microstructure of the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP. As shown in Fig. 1(f), two sets of distinct lattice spacing fringes of 0.169 and 0.557 nm correspond to the (300) plane of Ni1.25Fe0.75P and the (013) face of RP, respectively, illustrating the formation of an intimate interface between Ni1.25Fe0.75P and RP. Additionally, the EDS elemental mapping analysis revealed that P, Fe, and Ni were uniformly distributed in the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composite (Fig. 1(g)), which is consistent with the corresponding EDS spectra (Fig. S4). In addition, Ni, Fe, and P were uniformly distributed in the 0.77Ni2P/RP composite (Fig. S5), and 0.77Fe2P/RP (Fig. S6). These results further confirm that a series of Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites could be successfully prepared using the electrostatic self-assembly method. The lattice structures of the as-synthesized materials were determined using XRD. The XRD patterns of the as-prepared Ni y Fe1–y C2O4 (y = 1.00, 0.875, 0.750, 0.500, 0.375, and 0) precursors were shown in Fig. S7, the diffraction peaks of the as-prepared NiC2O4 and FeC2O4 corresponded to NiC2O4·2H2O (JCPDS: 14-0742) and FeC2O4·2H2O (JCPDS: 72–1305), respectively. Notably, the diffraction peak of Ni y Fe1–y C2O4 gradually shifted to a higher angle with an increase of y value due to the iron radius being larger than that of nickel. Once the Ni y Fe1–y C2O4 precursor was phosphatized, a series of Ni x Fe2–x P samples (x = 2.00, 1.75, 1.50, 1.25, 1.00, 0.750, and 0) were obtained. The corresponding XRD patterns of Ni x Fe2–x P are displayed in Figs. S8(a) and (b). The diffraction peaks of Ni2P and Fe2P are attributed to Ni2P (JCPDS: 03-0953) and Fe2P (JCPDS: 88-1803), respectively (Fig. S8(a)). Similar to the change of the precursor, the diffraction peak of Ni x Fe2–x P gradually shifted to a higher angle with the increase of x value (Fig. S8(b)), further verifying that the as-prepared Ni x Fe2–x P is a solid solution rather than a Ni2P/Fe2P heterojunction. After depositing Ni x Fe2–x P on the RP surface (Fig. 2(a) ), only the characteristic peak of RP (JCPDS: 44-0906) was observed because of the low amount of Ni x Fe2–x P deposited. Subsequently, taking Ni1.25Fe0.75P as an example, a series of Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composites were prepared to further confirm the successful preparation of the Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites. As depicted in Fig. S9, once the amount of Ni1.25Fe0.75P further increased to 2.32 wt%, the characteristic peaks of Ni1.25Fe0.75P and RP were distinctly observed in the Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites, moreover, the diffraction peak intensity of Ni1.25Fe0.75P increased gradually as the increase of Ni1.25Fe0.75P. These results confirm the successful preparation of the Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites. Subsequently, the major functional groups present in the obtained materials were detected by FTIR spectroscopy. As depicted in Fig. S10, the broad peaks at 687 and 1243 cm−1 of Ni1.25Fe0.75P signified the stretching vibrations of Fe/Ni–P and the P=O bonds, respectively [ 39 ]. Regarding RP, the P=O stretching vibration (1154 cm−1) and P–(OH)3 antisymmetric stretching vibration (997 cm−1) were identified in RP [ 9 ]. Additionally, the peaks at 1639 and 3140 cm−1 for RP and the peak at 1731 cm−1 for Ni1.25Fe0.75P were attributed to the variable vibration of absorbed water [ 9,39,56 ]. Once Ni1.25Fe0.75P was deposited on the RP, the stretching modes of the P=O bonds and P-(OH)3 coexisted in 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, indicating that 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP was successfully constructed. Subsequently, the XPS spectra of the RP, Ni2P, Fe2P, Ni1.25Fe0.75P, and 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP catalysts were obtained to determine the chemical states of the elements. As shown in Fig. S11(a), it can be observed that Ni, P, as well as Fe, P, could be found in Ni2P and Fe2P, respectively. As expected, Ni1.25Fe0.75P comprised Ni, Fe, and P. A similar phenomenon appeared in 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP; the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP hybrid was mainly composed of Ni, Fe, and P elements, which is consistent with the above-mentioned EDS analysis. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the P 2p XPS spectrum of Ni2P was fitted with three typical peaks. The peaks at 128.9 and 130.1 eV were assigned to P 2p 3/2 and P 2p 1/2 of Ni2P, respectively. Whereas the peak at 133.2 eV belonged to the P–O bond due to the slight oxidation of the Ni2P surface [ 57,58 ], which was also observed from O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. S11(b)). After introducing Fe into Ni2P, the binding energies (BEs) of Ni1.25Fe0.75P became more negative than those of Ni2P and Fe2P, indicating the formation of a Ni1.25Fe0.75P solid solution. When a small amount of Ni1.25Fe0.75P was deposited on the surface of RP, the BEs of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP showed a negative shift compared to RP but a positive shift compared to Ni1.25Fe0.75P, which is attributed to the strong interaction between Ni1.25Fe0.75P and RP in 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP. For Ni 2p XPS spectra of Ni2P (Fig. 2(c)), the peaks positioned at 852.7 and 869.9 eV were ascribed to Ni–P, and the peaks located around 856.2 and 873.6 eV correspond to Ni–O and Ni–POx [ 59,60 ]. In addition, two peaks at 861.3 and 878.7 eV were satellite peaks of the Ni species. Compared to that of Ni2P, the BEs of Ni1.25Fe0.75P displayed a negative shift. After depositing Ni1.25Fe0.75P onto the surface of the RP, the BEs of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP were more positive than those of Ni1.25Fe0.75P. The Fe spectra (Fig. 2(d)) are deconvoluted into four peaks; the peaks at 707.2 and 719.1 eV are ascribed to Fe–P. Moreover, the peaks at 712.6 and 725.9 eV are assigned to Fe–O, demonstrating the remnant of oxidized iron [ 61 ]. In contrast to the Ni 2p XPS spectra, the fitted Fe 2p peaks of Ni1.25Fe0.75P were shifted to lower BEs than those of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP and Fe2P. The above-mentioned consequence also verified the successful preparation of Ni1.25Fe0.75P and 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composite. To demonstrate that Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP was successfully synthesized, 77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP with a high content of Ni1.25Fe0.75P was prepared by increasing the Ni1.25Fe0.75P amount to 77 wt%. Subsequently, 77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP with a high content of Ni1.25Fe0.75P was utilized to detect the presence of Ni1.25Fe0.75P using XPS. As presented in Fig. S12, significant characteristic peaks of Ni and Fe were observed for 77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, indicating that Ni1.25Fe0.75P was successfully deposited on the surface of RP. In the rapid sequence, the optical absorption properties of the materials were probed using UV-vis DRS (Fig. S13). The pristine RP exhibited strong light absorption with an absorption edge at 673 nm. Once Ni1.25Fe0.75P was introduced, the absorption band edges of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composites were significantly redshifted as the loading content of Ni1.25Fe0.75P increased, demonstrating that Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst can further effectively expand the visible light absorption of RP. Soon afterward, the band gap energies (E g) of RP were calculated using Tauc’s function αhν = A(hν – E g) n/2 [ 62 ]. The n value of RP is four because of its indirect semiconductor character [ 63 ]. Thus, the E g value of RP was calculated to be 1.99 eV (Fig. 2(e)), which is in good agreement with reported values [ 14,64 ]. From the corresponding Mott-Schottky plots (Fig. 2(f)), it can be inferred that the flat-band potential (E fb) of RP is –0.490 V vs. Ag/AgCl (–0.290 V vs. NHE). In addition, the Mott-Schottky curve of RP has a positive slope, indicating that RP is an n-type semiconductor. For n-type semiconductor, the conduction band potential (E CB) value was 0.10 V more negative than E fb. Thus, the E CB of RP was –0.390 eV and the homologous valence band potential (E VB) was 1.60 eV according to the formula E VB = E CB + E g [ 65 ], which met the requirement for the photocatalytic oxidation of BA to BAD. According to the calculated DOS and corresponding band structure, it can be observed that Ni1.25Fe0.75P with a continuous band was primarily dominated by Ni 3d, Fe 3d, and P 2p states (Fig. 2(h)), illustrating that Ni1.25Fe0.75P could be an underlying candidate for cocatalyst. Unlike Ni1.25Fe0.75P, an overt band gap of approximately 1.83 eV was observed in RP, which was smaller than that of the experimental results owing to the restrictions of the DFT calculations [ 66 ]. Moreover, the CB of RP was mainly hybridized by the P 2p state. In contrast, the VB principally comprised the P 2s and P 2p orbitals (Fig. 2(g)). In addition, RP has a very low electron state density near the Fermi level, which is not beneficial for electron transport. When Ni1.25Fe0.75P was introduced into the RP system, electrons were effectively transferred from the RP to Ni1.25Fe0.75P. To investigate the cocatalyst effect of Ni x Fe2–x P in Ni x Fe2-x P/RP composites, the effect of loading amount of Ni x Fe2–x P was firstly optimized in DMF system containing BA under visible light and vacuum conditions. As shown in Figs. S14(a) and (b), taking Ni1.25Fe0.75P as an example, the photocatalytic activity of Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composites increased with increasing Ni1.25Fe0.75P deposition from 0.19 wt% until attaining 0.77 wt%, but then started to lower persistently. It can be found that under light illumination for 3 h, the production amounts of BAD for Ni1.25Fe0.75P, 0.19Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, 0.39Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, 1.55Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, 2.32Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP and RP photocatalysts were 0, 11.4, 15.75, 32.25, 22.58, 18.75 and 0.53 μmol g−1, respectively. The corresponding evolution amounts of H2 were 0, 12.53, 16.57, 34.31, 23.80, 19.98 and 0.58 μmol g−1, respectively. Thus, RP remarkably enhanced the photocatalytic activity of Ni1.25Fe0.75P with only 0.77% loading. A very small amount of Ni x Fe2–x P will result in inadequate reactive sites, but a large amount of Ni x Fe2–x P will lead to a mask effect owing to the strong visible-light absorption compared to pure RP. Furthermore, according to the yield of the co-produced H2 and BAD, the ratio of electrons to holes engaged in the redox reaction was approximately 1.0, suggesting a stoichiometric dehydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, control experiments revealed that neither the BAD product nor H2 was detected in the absence of photocatalysts or under dark conditions (Fig. S15), further confirming that catalysts and light sources are indispensable for achieving photocatalytic energy conversion. In the following experiments, the deposition of Ni x Fe2–x P was fixed at 0.77%, and the effect of the Ni/Fe content in Ni x Fe2–x P on the photocatalytic activity of the RP was further evaluated. As displayed in Figs. 3(a) and (b) , the BAD production for 0.77Ni2P/RP, 0.77Ni1.75Fe0.25P/RP, 0.77Ni1.5Fe0.5P/RP, 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, 0.77Ni1Fe1P/RP, 0.77Ni0.75Fe1.25P/RP, 0.77Fe2P/RP and RP photocatalysts were 7.35, 10.05, 18.90, 32.25, 15.60, 12.45, 1.95 and 0.53 μmol g−1, respectively, and the corresponding H2 evolution were 8.03, 10.71, 21.36, 34.31, 16.67, 13.17, 2.20 and 0.58 μmol g−1, respectively. The 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP demonstrated superior photocatalytic activity, which was 59.2-, 4.27-, 3.20-, 1.61-, 2.06-, 2.61 and 15.6 times greater than those of pure RP, 0.77Ni2P/RP, 0.77Ni1.75Fe0.25P/RP, 0.77Ni1.5Fe0.5P/RP, 0.77Ni1Fe1P/RP, 0.77Ni0.75Fe1.25P/RP, and 0.77Fe2P/RP, respectively. Based on the above analysis, the best composition of Ni x Fe2–x P was Ni1.25Fe0.75P, and the best loading amount of Ni x Fe2–x P was 0.77% in the RP system for selective photocatalytic oxidation of BA coupled with H2 evolution. Hence, 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP was chosen as the model cocatalyst for further investigation in the following experiments. The effect of monochromatic light wavelengths on the gas evolution rates of the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composites was also investigated to better understand the photocatalytic process of BA oxidation. As shown in Fig. 3(c), after irradiation, about 1.53, 1.16, 0.707, and 0.590 µmol g–1 h–1 of H2 were generated at 420, 500, 600, and 700 nm of monochromatic–light wavelengths, respectively, and their relevant photocatalytic quantum yield (AQY) were 0.00451%, 0.00413%, 0.00098%, and 0.00090%. Moreover, the generation trends of H2 and BAD were very close to those in the spectrum of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, implying that the photocatalytic process drove a synergistic photoredox reaction. Besides, the AQY of Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP reached 0.00451% under monochromatic light irradiation of 420 nm, which was ∞, ∞, and 1.21 times of RP (0%), Fe2P/RP (0%), and Ni2P/RP (0.00373%), respectively, indicating that the introduction of Ni1.25Fe0.75P could effectively enhance the quantum efficiency of RP (Fig. S16). In addition, a battery of aromatic alcohols with diverse substituent groups (RPhCH2OH, R = F, Cl, Br, OMe and Me) was used as the test substrate to expand the universality of the Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites for aromatic alcohol oxidation and H2 production. As shown in Fig. 3(d), 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP possesses outstanding photoredox activity for the oxidation of aromatic alcohols with electron-donating substituents (OMe and Me) or electron-withdrawing substituents (F, Cl, and Br), demonstrating that 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP serves as an effective photocatalyst for the selective oxidation of BA to BAD. Continuous photocatalytic experiments were performed to investigate the cyclic stabilities of pure RP and Ni x Fe2–x P/RP. As shown in Fig. S17, pure RP exhibited low photocatalytic redox activity after 18 h of continuous illumination owing to its fast electron-hole recombination rate and poor stability. Once the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst was introduced onto the RP surface, the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composite maintained good photocatalytic performance for BA oxidation coupled with H2 production (Fig. 3(e)). If an excessive amount of the catalyst is used, even the deactivated catalyst may have a high conversion rate during the cycle experiment. Considering that excessive use of the catalyst could mislead the cycling results with a high conversion rate, a cyclic experiment under lower conversion levels was implemented by lowering the dose of the catalyst to minimize the possibility of catalyst deactivation. The photocatalytic activity of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP decreased with decreasing catalyst loading (Fig. S18). Although the overall conversion rate was reduced, good and stable photocatalytic performance was maintained after 18 h of continuous illumination. The XRD (Fig. S19), and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas (Fig. S20) revealed that the phase and microstructure of the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composite did not significantly change after the reaction. In addition, the FT-IR spectra (Fig. S21), SEM images (Fig. S22), and XPS spectra (Fig. S23) of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP after cycling. No evident changes in the chemical structure and morphology were observed, which verified the remarkable stability of the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP material during photocatalytic BA oxidation coupled with H2 generation. It is well known that the separation efficiency of photon-generated carriers directly determined the properties of photocatalyst. To investigate the migration behavior of the carriers, TPC response, EIS, and PL spectra were recorded. First, the charge-transfer properties of Ni x Fe2–x P, zNi1.25Fe0.75P/RP, and 0.77Ni x Fe2–x P/RP were investigated. As shown in Fig. S24, the arc radius of Ni x Fe2–x P gradually decreased with increasing x until x reaches 1.25, started to increase. This phenomenon indicated that Ni1.25Fe0.75P had the fastest carrier migration ability and was more likely to promote the separation and migration of carriers. As expected, the RP modified by Ni1.25Fe0.75P presented a smaller Nernst circle radius than the other Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalysts (Fig. 3(f)), indicating that the deposition of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst facilitated the reduction in the interface migration resistance of RP. Moreover, with an increase in the amount of Ni1.25Fe0.75P deposited, the radius of the Nernst circle first decreased and then increased, which is consistent with the change in photocatalytic activity (Fig. S25). To obtain quantitative results, the impedance values obtained from the fitting are summarized in Table S2, and the corresponding simulated equivalent circuit is illustrated in Fig. 3(f). The fitted R s values indicate the Ohmic resistance between the material and its electrode, whereas R p represents the transfer resistance of the photogenerated carriers within the material. From the analysis of R s values, it is evident that various materials with minimal gaps exhibited similar Ohmic resistances across all samples. In contrast, there was a significant variation in R p values of the different photocatalysts. The R p values for RP, 0.77Ni2P/RP, 0.77Ni1.75Fe0.25P/RP, 0.77Ni1.5Fe0.5P/RP, 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP, 0.77Ni1Fe1P/RP, 0.77Ni0.75Fe1.25P/RP and 0.77Fe2P/RP photocatalysts presented enormous variations, which were 4.92×105, 2.77×105, 2.49×105, 4.09×104, 2.23×104, 9.64×104, 2.22×105 and 3.26×105 Ω, respectively. Notably, among these photocatalysts, 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP demonstrated the lowest R p value, indicating that it had a smaller interfacial migration resistance than the others. Subsequently, the TPC responses of the prepared samples were evaluated to determine their carrier separation efficiencies. As shown in Fig. 3(g), the pure RP component exhibits a low TPC signal. When Ni x Fe2–x P was combined with RP, the TPC signal of RP was significantly enhanced, indicating that the introduction of the Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalyst effectively accelerated the separation and migration of carriers originating from RP. In particular, RP modified by Ni1.25Fe0.75P presented a stronger TPC signal than those modified by the other Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalysts, illustrating that the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst had the best ability to accelerate carrier separation and migration in RP. Moreover, with an increase in the amount of Ni1.25Fe0.75P deposited, the TPC signal was first enhanced and then weakened, which is consistent with the change in photocatalytic activity (Fig. S26). Apparently, the RP with low surface charge transfer efficiency (η CTE) were around 36.8% (Fig. S27(a)). However, once the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst was introduced on RP, the η CTE of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP was significantly increased to 53.5% (Fig. S27(b)), further proving that the introduction of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst can boost the charge-transfer rate of the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP photocatalyst. The carrier recombination rate of the as-prepared sample was explored using PL spectra. After the introduction of Ni x Fe2–x P on the RP surface, the PL signal of RP decreased significantly (Fig. 3(h)), indicating that the introduction of the Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalyst could effectively inhibit the recombination of carriers, and the effect of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst was the most remarkable. In addition, the PL intensity of Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP changed with the variation of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P deposition amount. When the deposition amount of Ni1.25Fe0.75P reached 0.77 wt%, the 0.77Ni x Fe2–x P/RP presented the lowest PL intensity (Fig. S28), indicating that the amount of deposited Ni1.25Fe0.75P also plays a major role in inhibiting carrier recombination. Finally, the average lifetimes of the photon–generated carriers in the samples were determined using TRPL. The decay curves were fitted using a biexponential decay function: y = y 0 + A 1 e –x/τ1 + A 2 e –x/τ2, and the average PL lifetimes (τ ave) were calculated according to the formula [ 67 ]: τ ave = (A 1 τ 1 2 + A 2 τ 2 2)/(A 1 τ 1 + A 2 τ 2). The homologous three-exponential fitting results are presented in Table S3. The calculated average lifetimes of Ni1.25Fe0.75P, RP, 0.77Fe2P/RP, 0.77Ni2P/RP, and 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP were 4.229, 4.230, 4.183, 3.974, and 3.719 ns, respectively. As shown in Fig. 3(i), after the introduction of the Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalyst to RP, the transient lifetimes of the 0.77Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites were strongly quenched, leading to shorter average lifetimes than those of pure RP. Among the 0.77Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composites, 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP exhibited the shortest decay lifetime, indicating that the photoexcited electrons in RP quickly migrated to Ni1.25Fe0.75P. These results further confirmed that the introduction of the Ni x Fe2–x P cocatalyst effectively promoted the separation and migration of the photogenerated carriers of the RP. It is considered that the microstructure directly affects the adsorption performance of the photocatalyst; thus, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured to probe the specific surface areas of the as-prepared photocatalysts. All isotherms with a type IV hysteresis loop indicated the presence of mesopores (Fig. 4(a) ), which was also verified by the pore diameter distribution plots (inset in Fig. 4(a)). As shown in Table S4, the specific surface area of Ni1.25Fe0.75P was between those of unitary Ni2P and Fe2P owing to the formation of bimetallic phosphides. Once Ni1.25Fe0.75P combined with RP, the specific surface area of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP increased significantly from 10.07 m2 g–1 to 63.33 m2 g–1, mainly attributing to the large specific surface area of RP (64.43 m2 g–1). It is well known that specific surface area directly affects the photocatalytic properties of the photocatalyst. It is necessary to exclude the specific surface area to explore the main active centers responsible for the enhanced photocatalytic properties. Thus, the surface area–normalized H2 generation rates for 0.77Fe2P/RP, 0.77Ni2P/RP, and 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP are discussed. The corresponding BET and H2 generation rate (k) were exhibited in Fig. S29 and are summarized in Table S5. Subsequently, the k values were normalized to the corresponding surface areas, denoted as k'. It can be seen that the 0.77Fe2P/RP and 0.77Ni2P/RP presented weak k' values, which were 0.009498 and 0.04174 μmol h−1 m−2, respectively (Table S5). Conversely, when the Ni1.25Fe0.75P was introduced, the k' value of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP was increased by 0.1727 μmol h−1 m−2 and 0.1405 μmol h−1 m−2, respectively, in comparison with the 0.77Fe2P/RP and 0.77Ni2P/RP, indicating that bimetallic phosphides could provide multiple active sites to participate in the reduction of H+ to H2. Subsequently, DFT calculations were used to further investigate the adsorption energies (E ads) of BA (Fig. 4(b)). The optimized structures of Ni2P, Ni1.25Fe0.75P, and Fe2P are shown in Figs. S30. It can be seen that the E ads of BA on Ni2P and RP were –0.45 and –1.07 eV, respectively. Once both of them were coupled, the E ads of BA on the Ni2P side and RP side of Ni2P/RP were –0.42 and –1.09 eV, illustrating that BA was more easily adsorbed on the RP side of Ni2P/RP composite. Similar phenomena were observed for Fe2P/RP (Fig. 4(c)) and Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composites (Fig. 4(d)). Notably, the BA adsorption energy on the RP side of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composite was more negative than those of Ni2P/RP and Fe2P/RP, indicating that the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst was more conducive for promoting BA adsorption on the RP surface. In summary, the introduction of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst effectively improves the adsorption performance, promotes the separation and migration of photogenerated carriers, and improves the photocatalytic redox activity of RP. To probe the role of active substances and free radical intermediates during photocatalytic coupling of BA oxidation with H2 production, the capture test was performed using TEOA, CCl4, BHT, and IPA as the trapping agents of the hole (h +), electron (e−), C-center radical, and hydroxyl radicals (•OH), respectively [ 68–71 ]. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , the reduction and oxidation products remained almost unchanged after the addition of IPA. Nevertheless, once TEOA or BHT was added, evident inhibitory redox activity was observed. In contrast, after the addition of CCl4, the oxidation product remained nearly unchanged, but the reduction product was clearly suppressed. The aforementioned consequences illustrated that the h + and C-center radicals were the primary active species involved in the photocatalytic oxidation reaction. In contrast, the e− was merely the dominating free radical that participated in the reduction reaction. To acquire more information about the active intermediate in the as-prepared sample, EPR was performed using DMPO as a spin-trapping reagent. As shown in Fig. 5(b), no free radical signals were detected for RP, Ni1.25Fe0.75P, and 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP in the dark. After exposure to visible light, typical EPR signal peaks were observed, which were assigned to the carbon-centered free radicals. Besides, the nitrogen hyperfine division (α-N) and hydrogen hyperfine division (α-H) of nitrogen was measured to be 16.1 and 21.8, respectively, attributing to the DMPO-CH(OH)Ph (Fig. 5(c)) [ 72 ]. In addition, the EPR intensity of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP was significantly stronger than that of pristine RP and Ni1.25Fe0.75P under light irradiation, indicating that the loading of Ni1.25Fe0.75P distinctly increased the formation of •CH(OH)Ph free radicals, thereby improving the photocatalytic activity. Therefore, in-situ FTIR was used to monitor the photocatalytic process of BA oxidation coupled with H2 evolution over 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP. As shown in Fig. 5(d), absorption peaks at 1015, 1131, 1357, 1456, and 1507 cm‒1 were detected in the dark, corresponding to the C–O, in-plane CH, C–OH, scissor CH2, and C=C bending vibrations of BA, respectively [ 73–75 ]. Upon exposure to light, a new characteristic peak of the C=O group assigned to BAD appeared at 1683 cm‒1 [ 76 ]. Moreover, the absorption peaks of the C=O group gradually increased with increasing irradiation time, confirming that BA was dehydrogenated and oxidized to BAD under visible light. In quick succession, the Gibbs free energies were calculated to further research the bond cleavage process of Cα-H over pristine Ni1.25Fe0.75P, RP, and 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composites. It can be seen from Figs. 5(e)–(g) that the crucial intermediate of •CH(OH)Ph radical was formed via Cα-H cleavage, which was the rate-determining step for BA oxidation. The Cα-H fractured to form •CH(OH)Ph radicals over pristine Ni1.25Fe0.75P (Fig. 5(e)) and RP (Fig. 5(f)), which needed to overcome the energy barrier of 1.85 and 1.07 eV, respectively. Once the Ni1.25Fe0.75P combined with RP, the energy barrier of this step over 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composites was markedly reduced to 0.83 eV (Fig. 5(g)), confirming that the introduction of Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst effectively lowered the energy barrier of the reaction. Subsequently, the transfer direction of the photoexcited electrons was determined using in-situ XPS. This is shown in Fig. S31(a), with no additional peaks appearing for 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP after irradiation. This indicates that the structure of 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP could not be changed by the incident light source. For the high-resolution Ni 2p spectra, the fitting peak of Ni 2p presented a more negative offset after illumination than before illumination (Fig. 6(a) ), indicating the increased electron density of Ni. A similar phenomenon was observed in the Fe 2p spectra (Fig. 6(b)); the BEs of Fe 2p shifted negatively after illumination. Unlike the Ni 2p and Fe 2p spectra, the BEs of the P 2p spectra shifted positively under visible-light irradiation (Fig. 6(c)). Ni1.25Fe0.75P with continuous bandgap energy is difficult to excite by light irradiation. Thus, the positive shift of the P 2p peak is attributed to the efficient transfer of photoinduced electrons from RP to Ni1.25Fe0.75P. In contrast to the above phenomenon, the BEs of O 1s (Fig. S31(b)) of the 0.77Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP composite hardly changed before and after illumination, illustrating that the surface-adsorbed oxides and water molecules did not interfere with electron migration. These results further confirmed that the photoexcited electrons from RP tended to accumulate on Ni1.25Fe0.75P under light irradiation. The work functions of RP, Ni1.25Fe0.75P, and Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP were determined using DFT calculations. As shown in Figs. 6(d)–(f), the work functions (Φ) of RP, Ni1.25Fe0.75P and Ni1.25Fe0.75P/RP were calculated to be 5.13, 6.32, and 5.43 eV versus vacuum level, demonstrating that the corresponding Fermi levels (E f) were –3.03, –2.16, and –2.28 eV, respectively. The E f of the RP was lower E f than that of the Ni1.25Fe0.75P cocatalyst (Fig. 6(g)). When RP and Ni1.25Fe0.75P were in close contact, the electrons moved from Ni1.25Fe0.75P to RP until the E f reached equilibrium at –2.28 eV, resulting in the downward band edge for RP due to the accumulation of negative charges. Once exposed to visible light, the built-in electric field guided the migration of photoexcited electrons from the conduction band (CB) of RP to Ni1.25Fe0.75P, which is consistent with the in situ XPS analysis. Based on the aforementioned analyses, a tentative mechanism is proposed for the photocatalytic oxidation of BA coupled with H2 evolution over Ni x Fe2–x P/RP (Fig. 7 ). Once light irradiation, the RP in Ni x Fe2–x P/RP composite was firstly excited to produce photogenerated electrons (e−) and holes (h +), subsequently, the e− could transfer from the CB of RP to the surface of Ni x Fe2–x P, meanwhile, the h + retained on the VB of RP. Originally, h + oxidizes BA to produce carbon-centered radicals, which interact with each other to form BAD. Even the photogenerated h + can directly oxidize BA to generate BAD. In quick succession, the releasing H+ of BA oxidation could be reduced by e− to produce H2, thereby, realizing the full utilization of carriers in Ni x Fe2–x P/RP photocatalyst system. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts, Ni x Fe2−x P, with tunable structures and overpotential, were developed to enhance the photocatalytic redox activity of RP, facilitating electron transfer from RP to the bimetallic reactive sites. The RP regulated by bimetallic phosphide Ni x Fe2−x P cocatalysts demonstrated better photocatalytic oxidation-reduction activity compared to that regulated by monometallic phosphide Ni2P and Fe2P cocatalysts. In particular, the RP regulated by Ni1.25Fe0.75P shows the best photocatalytic performance, ascribing that the Ni x Fe2−x P cocatalysts could not only provide abundant active sites but also lower the reaction energy barrier of RP, thus accelerating the photocatalytic activity. The combination of the experimental and theoretical calculation revealed the optimized composition and electronic structure of Ni1.25Fe0.75P, which exhibits good electrical conductivity and provides abundant active sites. The findings of this study will provide comprehensive guidance for the rational design of bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts, help optimize the surface properties of primary catalysts, and offer theoretical insights into the regulation of multi-metallic center photocatalytic systems in future applications. coredata.dc:description: Although bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts have attracted considerable interest in photocatalysis research owing to their advantageous thermodynamic characteristics, superstable and efficient cocatalysts have rarely been produced through the modulation of their structure and composition. In this study, a series of bimetallic nickel-iron phosphide (Ni x Fe2–x P, where 0 < x < 2) cocatalysts with controllable structures and overpotentials were designed by adjusting the atomic ratio of Ni/Fe onto nonmetallic elemental red phosphorus (RP) for the photocatalytic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) coupled with hydrogen production. The catalysts exhibited an outstanding photocatalytic activity for benzaldehyde and a high H2 yield. The RP regulated by bimetallic phosphide cocatalysts (Ni x Fe2–x P) demonstrated higher photocatalytic oxidation-reduction activity than that regulated by monometallic phosphide cocatalysts (Ni2P and Fe2P). In particular, the RP regulated by Ni1.25Fe0.75P exhibited the best photocatalytic performance. In addition, experimental and theoretical calculations further illustrated that Ni1.25Fe0.75P, with the optimized electronic structure, possessed good electrical conductivity and provided strong adsorption and abundant active sites, thereby accelerating electron migration and lowering the reaction energy barrier of RP. This finding offers valuable insights into the rational design of highly effective cocatalysts aimed at optimizing the photocatalytic activity of composite photocatalysts.
